Description: Mould-made scarab in glazed composition; back very damaged, with no details of modelling remaining, at side, very limited incised grooves indicating legs; underside bearing a poorly preserved hieroglyphic inscription arranged horizontally with from right to left falcon, men-draughtboard sign and sun-disc; inscription possibly stamped rather than incised (?); longitudinally pierced; glaze lost; yellowish off-white core; very worn.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by City Art Gallery and Museum, Bristol. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Falcon, sometimes wearing a crown or with a flail, is a recurring motif for various compositions found on scarabs and scaraboids produced at the “Scarab Factory” (on its various productions, see Webb forthcoming). Though the hieroglyphic signs could have just some magical value, it seems more plausible that this is either a cryptographic reading for the name of Amun / Amun-Ra (on the cryptic writing of the name of Amun: Drioton 1957) or an abbreviated form for the Horus name of Psamtek II (Hölbl 1979, 165). This scarab belongs to a type, widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and Southern Russia (Gorton 1996, 93-107, type XXVIII B, subtype B42-57a, see especially B42 for this piece). The hieroglyphs depicted on the underside can be found on several scarabs and scaraboids of various shapes discovered in Naukratis (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII nos. 47-48, 50): BM 1886,0401.1630 and BM 1886,0401.1631; Boston, Museum of Fine Arts 88.865; Bristol, City Art Gallery & Museum H3808. Drioton, E. 1957, 'Trigrammes d'Amon', Festschrift Hermann Junker zum 80. Geburtstag (Wiener Zeitschrift für die Kunde des Morgenlandes 54), Wien, 11-33. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford. Hölbl, G. 1979, Beziehungen der ägyptischen Kultur zu Altitalien (EPRO 62), Leiden. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London. This type was widely distributed in the Mediterranean area and in South Russia (Gorton 1996, 103-107, type XXVIII B, see especially 71-88 for this piece). For a similar association of signs on a blue Egyptian scarab from Naukratis: BM 1886,0401.1667. Gardner, E. A. 1888, Naukratis. Part II (Sixth Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, Pl. XVIII, 42. Gorton, A.F. 1996, Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites, Oxford, 103-107, type XXVIII B. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London, Pl. XXXVII, 99-104 (other variants).
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 49) (similar motif, but better preserved)
Gorton 1996 / Egyptian and Egyptianizing scarabs: a typology of steatite, faience, and paste scarabs from Punic and other Mediterranean sites (p.102, Type XXVIII B42) (same type)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OC.117) (phase 3)
